direction.raw_text: ...And a good lady, and wise and virtuous. I nurse her daughter that you talk'd withal..." During RALPH'S lines (which are continuous) WILL stands in the shadow behind the curtain, alone, agitated. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE. DAY. RALPH AS NURSE "I tell you, he that can lay hold of her (he makes the money sign) Shall have the chinks."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Is she a Capulet" Oh dear account. My life is my foe's debt." NOL, AS "BENVOLIO," at a party, carrying a goblet, tipsy, enters the scene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Away, be gone, the sport is at best." VIOLA, about to make her exit, has her hand holding the curtain at the gap. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. BEHIND THE CURTAIN. DAY. WILL is kissing her hand. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Ay, so I fear; the more is my unrest." INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. BEHIND THE CURTAIN. DAY. VIOLA comes through the curtain. WILL and VIOLA kiss, dangerously--they are in a narrow space, hidden from the general backstage area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Come hither nurse. What is yond gentleman?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh let it be night! INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: know not."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Go ask his name--If he be married, My grave is like to be my wedding bed." INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. BEHIND THE CURTAIN. DAY. "JULIET'S" line bits WILL between the eyes. WILL pulls away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, do not go
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must. I must INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. BACKSTAGE. DAY. As WILL races up the ladder to his writer's corner, the rehearsal can be heard continuing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "His name is Romeo, and a Montague, The only son of your great enemy."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Terrible! INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. WRITER'S CORNER. DAY. WILL arrives at the top of the building in his writer's corner. He spins around once in a circle, rubs his hands together and spits on the floor. His manuscript is all over the table. We take a peak at the lines he has already written. INSERT MANUSCRIPT: "But soft, what light through yonder window breaks? It is the east and Juliet is the sun." VIOLA'S VOICE OVER speaks the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "But soft, what light through yonder window breaks? It is the east and Juliet is the sun!" INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. EVENING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Arise fair sun and kill the envious moon Who is already sick and pale with grief That thou her maid art far more fair than she..." VIOLA is in bed, reading the lines from the manuscript page. WILL is in bed with her, reading with her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Will!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, some of it is speakable. She has to speak through WILL'S kisses, he is nibbling at her neck and shoulders and she has to bat him away with the pages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "It is my lady, O it is my love! O that she knew she were!" INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE. DAY. VIOLA continues the speech, edge-to-edge, now in rehearsal, with SAM as "JULIET" sighing on the balcony above her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "The brightness of her cheek would shame those stars As daylight doth a lamp. Her eyes in heaven Would through the airy region stream so bright That birds would sing and think it were not night. See how she leans her cheek upon her hand. O that I were a glove upon that hand, That I might touch that cheek.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Ay me."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "She speaks. Oh speak again bright angel..." We have abandoned real time. The scene continues CROSS CUT between the STAGE and VIOLA'S BED. INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. EVENING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Oh Romeo, Romeo, wherefore art thou Romeo? Deny thy father and refuse thy name." INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE. DAY SAM AS JULIET "Or if thou wilt not, be but sworn my love And I'll no longer be a Capulet."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Shall I hear more or shall I speak at this?" INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. NIGHT. WILL and VIOLA in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "What man art thou that thus bescreen'd in night So stumblest on my counsel?" INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE/AUDITORIUM. NIGHT. It's become late and the rehearsal is continuing by torchlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...By a name I know not how to tell thee who I am: My name, dear saint, is hateful to myself Because it is an enemy to thee..." We see that a group of the other actors have drifted "out front," drawn by the scene. FENNYMAN is there entranced. Clearly, this stuff is a cut above the normal. INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. NIGHT WILL, undressed, strides around the room, feeding "JULIET'S" lines to VIOLA in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "The orchard walls are high and hard to climb, And the place death, considering who thou art, If any of my kinsmen find thee here. If they do see thee, they will murder thee." INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Alack, there lies more peril in thine eye, Than twenty of their swords! Look thou but sweet, And I am proof against their enmity."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would not for the world!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have night's cloak to hide me from their eyes; And but thou love me, let them find me here. INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. NIGHT. WILL and VIOLA are both out of bed, halfway though dressing. Still rehearsing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Good night, good night. As sweet repose and rest Come to thy heart as that within my breast. O wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's my line!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, but it is mine too! INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wilt thou leave me so unsatisfied?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "What satisfaction can'st thou have tonight?"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "The exchange of thy love's faithful vow for mine." INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. NIGHT. WILL and VIOLA are back on the bed, kissing and making love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "My bounty is as boundless as the sea, My love as deep:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the more I give to thee The more I have, for both are infinite." Outside the NURSE is knocking on the door and calling. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hear some noise within. Dear love, adieu." RALPH, the Nurse, call's "JULIET!" off stage. INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. NIGHT VIOLA (calling to the NURSE who is outside) Anon, good Nurse INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. OUTSIDE VIOLA'S BEDROOM. NIGHT. The NURSE listens at the door. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Anon, good Nurse--Sweet Montague be true." INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Stay but a little, I will come again." VIOLA slaps him playfully for his vulgarity, and then kisses him. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Stay but a little, I will come again." SAM leaves the balcony through the curtain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Oh blessed blessed night." INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. NIGHT. It is night. They have just made love. Suddenly it is very still.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: am feared, Being in night, all this but a dream, Too flattering- sweet to be substantial." INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. BACKSTAGE. DAY. Onstage, the scene continues. Backstage NED ALLEYN is working his way upstairs. He passes by RALPH (the Nurse) who has a couple of words "of," as it were, in "JULIET'S" chamber.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...All my fortunes at thy foot I'll lay, And follow thee my lord throughout the world."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Madam!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: come, anon--But if thou meanest not well, I do beseech thee--"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Madam!"
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By and by I come to cease thy strife and leave me to my grief. A thousand times good night!" SAM exits (i.e. enters to us) through the curtain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot move in this dress! and it makes me look like a pig! I have no neck in this pig dress! (and then hearing his cue from "ROMEO") Oh, she's off again! She says she's going and then she doesn't INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. WRITER'S CORNER. DAY. NED is arriving. WILL is busy writing. PETER is there, holding the pages WILL has completed, and waiting for WILL to finish his page. PETER is reading his pages. WILL sees NED arrive. He gives his page to PETER.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right. Typical!, says WILL'S face. Peter departs, leaving the field to NED. WILL braces himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ned...I know...I know
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The title won't do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Romeo and Juliet--just a suggestion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Ned. The whole exchange is in ironic code, between old soldiers. NED nods curtly and turns to descend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are a gentleman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you are a Warwickshire shit-house. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE/AUDITORIUM. DAY. PETER is just handing the pages HENSLOWE in the auditorium. HENSLOWE has acquired a performing dog. The dog does somersaults tirelessly. As PETER hands over the pages, he shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean, no dog of any kind? FENNYMAN, the born-again theatre groupie shushes HENSLOWE and looks daggers at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Friar married them in secret, then Ned gets into a fight with one of the Capulets, Romeo tries to stop them, he gets in Ned's way, I mean in Mercutio's way, so Tybalt kills Mercutio and then Romeo kills Tybalt. Then the Prince banishes him from Verona.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That must be when he goes on the voyage and gets shipwrecked on the island of the Pirate King. FENNYMAN can't hear it. He storms over. Kicks the dog, roars at HENSLOWE .
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cease your prattling! Get out! (to the stage where the action has paused) A thousand apologies!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Good night, good night. Parting is such sweet sorrow That I shall say good night till it be morrow." INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. MORNING. A sunbeam wakes the lovers. Sunday morning. Church bells. VIOLA wakes with a start. Something is bothering her, she can't think what. WILL calms her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sunday...it is Sunday. He brings her back down to the pillow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found something in my sleep. The Friar who married them will take up their destinies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, but it will end well for love?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In heaven, perhaps. It is not a comedy I am writing now. A broad river divides my lovers--family, duty, fate--as unchangeable as nature.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, this is not life, Will. This is a stolen season. Suddenly there is a great racket heard from downstairs...a man shouting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not ready? Where is she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be patient, my lord, she is dressing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you ask Her Majesty to be patient?! VIOLA remembers. She jumps up and gives a cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sunday! Greenwich! INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. OUTSIDE VIOLA'S BEDROOM. MORNING. The NURSE is barring the stairs to WESSEX.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, pay attention, Nursy. The Queen, Gloriana Regina, God's Chosen Vessel, the Radiant One, who shines her light on us, is at Greenwich today, and prepared, during the evening's festivities, to bestow her gracious favour on my choice of wife--and if we're late for lunch, the old boot will not forgive. So you get you to my lady's chamber and produce her with or without her undergarments. INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. MORNING. VIOLA has her dress on and is putting on her shoes. WILL, in his underwear is in mid-argument.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cannot! Not for the Queen herself!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What will you have me do? Marry you instead?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To be the wife of a poor player?--can I wish that for Lady Viola, except in my dreams? And yet I would, if I were free to follow my desire in the harsh light of day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You follow your desire freely enough in the night. So, if that is all, to Greenwich I go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I will go with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cannot, Wessex will kill you
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know how to fight!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stage fighting! (turn to him) Oh, Will! As Thomas Kent my heart belongs to you but as Viola the river divides us, and I will marry Wessex a week from Saturday. INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. OUTSIDE VIOLA'S BEDROOM DOWNSTAIRS HALL. MORNING. The ranting from WESSEX has continued
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By heaven, I will drag her down, by the Queen's command And is cut off short as VIOLA'S door opens at the top of the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, my lord!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah! My lady! The tide waits for no man, but I swear it would wait for you! VIOLA comes down the stairs. Behind her WILL appears gowned and bonneted. He has also assumed a country accent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here we come at last, my lord!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you bringing your laundry woman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her chaperone. My lady's country cousin. (arriving with a curtsey) My, but you be a handsome gallant, just as she said! You may call me Miss Wilhelmina!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On a more fortuitous occasion, perhaps
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, my lord, you will not shake me off, she never needed me more, I sear by your breeches! EXT. GREENWICH PALACE. NIGHT. Fireworks explode in the evening sky over Greenwich, a royal palace, crowded now with noble guests. EXT. GREENWICH PALACE. TERRACE. NIGHT. The way these royal routs work is that guest mill about, chatting, bowing and generally behaving gallantly, while QUEEN ELIZABETH creates a vortex around her as she passes through the throng, occasionally honouring somebody with a couple of words, until she arrives thankfully at the best chair...where she establishes a headquarters. Her current LORD IN WAITING ferries the lucky few forward to a brief audience with the QUEEN, each giving way to the next. VIOLA and WESSEX are, respectively, dipping and bowing as they are greeted by people who know them...Will, in close attendance, joins in gratuitously, bowing until VIOLA nudges him and reminds him to curtsey instead. The QUEEN'S LORD IN WAITING plucks WESSEX'S sleeve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Queen asks for you. Answer well. The LORD IN WAITING ushers VIOLA through the crowd. WILL starts to follow. WESSEX takes him by the arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there a man?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A man, my lord?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was a man, poet--a theatre poet, I heard--does he come to the house?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A theatre poet?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An insolent penny-a-page rogue, Marlowe, he said, Christopher Marlowe--has he been to the house?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marlowe? Oh yes, he is the one, lovely waistcoat, shame about the poetry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That dog! ANGLE on the QUEEN. The LORD IN WAITING has presented VIOLA. VIOLA speaks from a frozen curtsey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stand up straight, girl. VIOLA straightens. The QUEEN examines her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have seen you. You are the one who comes to all the plays--at Whitehall, at Richmond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Majesty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you love so much?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your Majesty
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Speak out! I know who I am. Do you love stories of kings and queens? Feats of arms? Or is it courtly love?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love theatre. To have stories acted for me by a company of fellows is indeed
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are not acted for you, they are acted for me. VIOLA remains silent, in apology. ANGLE on WILL. He is watching and listening. He has never seen the QUEEN so close. He is fascinated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And--?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I love poetry above all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Above Lord Wessex? She looks over VIOLA'S shoulder and VIOLA realises WESSEX has moved up behind her. WESSEX bows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My Lord--when you cannot find your wife you had better look for her at the playhouse. The COURTIERS titter at her pleasantry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But playwrights teach nothing about love, they make it pretty, they make it comical, or they make it lust. They cannot make it true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, but they can! She has forgotten herself. The COURTIERS gasp. The QUEEN considers her. WESSEX looks furious. WILL is touched.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean...Your Majesty, they do not, they have not, but I believe there is one who can
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lady Viola is...young in the world. Your Majesty is wise in it. Nature and truth are the very enemies of playacting. I'll wager my fortune.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you were here because you had none. Titters again. WESSEX could kill somebody.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, no one will take your wager, it seems.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifty pounds! Shock and horror. QUEEN ELIZABETH is the only person amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifty pounds! A very worthy sum on a very worthy question. Can a play show us the very truth and nature of love? I bear witness to the wager, and will be the judge of it as occasion arises. (which wins a scatter of applause. She gathers her skirts and stands) I have not seen anything to settle it yet. (she moves away, everybody bowing and scraping) So--the fireworks will be soothing after the excitements of Lady Viola's audience. (and now she is next to WESSEX who is bowing low. Intimately to him) Have her then, but you are a lordly fool. She has been plucked since I saw her last, and not by you. It takes a woman to know it. The QUEEN passes by, and as WESSEX comes vertical again, we see his face a mask of furious realisation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marlowe! INT. BURBAGE'S HOUSE. ENTRANCE. DAY. CHRISTOPHER MARLOWE shuts the door behind him. Above him, the ceiling creaks to the rhythm of copulation. He has a sheaf of manuscript pages in his hand. He goes to the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burbage! The creaking stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's there? INT. BURBAGE'S HOUSE. STAIRS. DAY. MARLOWE ascends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marlowe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kit! INT. BURBAGE'S HOUSE. BEDROOM. DAY. MARLOWE enters, ignoring the situation on the bed where ROSALINE is astride BURBAGE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are playing my Faustus this afternoon. Don't spend yourself in sport.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This afternoon!--we'll still be here this afternoon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want, Kit?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My Massacre at Paris is complete.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have the last act?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have the money?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tomorrow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then tomorrow you will have the pages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait! (to ROSALINE) Will you desist!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty pounds on delivery
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is money to me like us? Besides, if I need a play, I have another waiting, a comedy by Shakespeare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Romeo?--he gave it to Henslowe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I am to Deptford now, I leave my respects, Miss Rosaline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gave Shakespeare two sovereigns for Romeo!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did. But Ned Alleyn and the Admiral's Men have the playing of it as the Rose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Treachery! BURBAGE rouses himself violently, throwing ROSALINE off the bed. The glass bracelet is flung from her wrist. It breaks on the floor, releasing a strip of paper. BURBAGE picks it up. What he reads on it does not please him: it is WILL'S signature.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Traitor and thief! EXT. STREETS. DAY. BURBAGE and a solid wedge of the CHAMBERLAIN'S MEND are cleaving a path through the crowds. Their faces are grim. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE/AUDITORIUM/UNDER THE STAGE. DAY. We are in Act III Scene I. NED ALLEYN as "MERCUTIO" and NOL as "BENVOLIO", and two "MONTAGUE" sidekicks are in occupation of the stage, when the "CAPULETS" swagger in, four of them headed by JAMES HEMMINGS as "TYBALT."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "By my head, here comes the Capulets."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "By my heel, I care not."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Follow me close, for I will speak to them. (with bombast to "MERCUTIO") Gentlemen, good e'en: a word with one of you." NED comes out of character.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you going to do it like that? And before the humbled actor can reply NED continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And but one word with one of us? Couple it with something, make it a word and a blow. But suddenly six more men and a dog invade the stage, ready to fight. BURBAGE and the CHAMBERLAIN'S MEN have arrived to avenge BURBAGE'S honour with swords, clubs, and a bucket (containing pig swill).
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is that thieving hack who can't keep his pen in his own ink pot!? WILL has already leapt up onto the stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is this rabble?! BURBAGE aims a blow at WILL, who ducks and grabs a stave from the nearest actor, and parries the blow. He swings at BURBAGE, a CHAMBERLAIN'S MAN swings at WILL, THOMAS cries out, someone else slashes the stage hangings bringing down the drapes, and in a moment the ADMIRAL'S MEN and the CHAMBERLAIN'S MEN, using their much rehearsed skills, are brawling with weapons and fist, using everything short of unbuttoned rapiers. CRAB, the dog, is yapping and snapping at any legs he can reach. HENSLOWE, a little slow to catch up on the situation, checks the page in his hand. FENNYMAN, much slower to catch up, watches enthralled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wonderful, wonderful! And a dog! But now HENSLOWE has worked out that these actors don't belong, nor does the scene. he enters the fray, but his interest is protecting his property. Big burly RALPH is using a couple of unlit torches as weapons; he breaks one of them over an enemy's back and HENSLOWE turns on RALPH HENSLOWE Not with my props! VIOLA is doing well enough, tripping up an enemy with a well-judged stave, and then using it to deflect a blow aimed at WILL VIOLA Will! What--?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A literary feud. Quite normal. Then he is smashed over the head. He falls off the stage taking VIOLA with him. Under the stage is a space (known as Hell) and WILL shoves VIOLA into this space.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay hid! He gets back onto the stage, where the goings on are worthy of the Four Musketeers and Robin Hood combined, with SAM GOSSE, dressed as "JULIET," fighting with the best of them. There is a stack of cushions, stored for the expensive seats, and as the stack s knocked over, NED ALLEYN and others grab cushions to use as shields. Soon cushions are being ripped, and the air is full of flying feathers. The trap door in the stage opens, VIOLA'S head pops up. She looks around and, surrounded by milling legs and floating feathers, a boot catches her sideways and half knocks her wig off. In danger of having her cover blown, she ducks down again, leaving the trap open just nicely for Will to plummet down it. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. UNDER THE STAGE. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I dreamed last night of a shipwreck. You were cast ashore in a far country. They embrace and kiss. In a moment they are in a world of their own. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. UNDER THE STAGE. DAY. The battle rages. FENNYMAN, alone now in the auditorium, continues to watch entranced. It's the greatest show he's ever seen. HENSLOWE is desperately trying to rescue odd props that have been seconded to the fight. Someone picks up a tree that is to be used in Romeo. HENSLOWE yells.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We need that for the balcony scene! FENNYMAN notices this, and it rings a distant bell. He looks around the realises that some of these faces are unfamiliar. The tree comes crashing down on RALPH'S head. FENNYMAN looks at HENSLOWE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My poor Rose! He collapses on to a broken bench. FENNYMAN comes over to him, grabs the script pages from his pocket, and consults them to confirm what he has now begun to suspect: that this scene is not in them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My investment! LAMBERT!!! LAMBERT has been sleeping peacefully through this, but wakes to his master's call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ! HENSLOWE attempts to intervene.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want no more trouble, Mr. Fennyman. As I explained to you, the theatre business
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Henslowe, you pound of tripe, in my business I would be out of business if I had your courage, so don't tell me about business And he delivers a telling blow to a passing CHAMBERLAIN'S MAN, who wheels off the stage. LAMBERT meanwhile is making short work of the rest of the opposition, receiving help with the thorny business of identification from SAM. Stray members of the CHAMBERLAIN'S MEN are running from the theatre, as BURBAGE, fighting a heroic last stand, is tipped backwards by FENNYMAN off the stage and into a bucket of swill. A PAUSE. Then NED starts applauding. The others, weary from fighting, start applauding too, from all levels of the theatre. FENNYMAN looks around, starting to beam, as a din of encores and bravos engulf him. A star! INT. BROTHEL. NIGHT. The victorious army of actors bursts into the brothel, FENNYMAN at their head. He owns the brothel. The place is already crowded with WHORES and CUSTOMERS. It's a party.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A famous victory! Kegs and legs. Open and on the house! Oh what happy hour! (and grabbing a RADDLED WHORE) Poxy Pol! You keep yourself to yourself I'll not have you infecting my investment!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this a tavern?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is also a tavern. WILL sits her down in THE COMPANY and takes the chair next to her A PRETTY WHORE immediately sits on WILL'S knee and kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I remember you! The poet! VIOLA furiously pulls the PRETTY WHORE off WILL'S lap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One at a time, one at a time!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, he's a pretty one! Tell me your story while I tickle your fancy!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh!--it's--it's--oh, it's a house of ill- repute!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is, Thomas, but of good reputation. Come, there is no harm in a drink. Glasses are shoved into their hands. Everyone has a glass. Except RALPH RALPH (declining the glass) Never when I'm working! The PRETTY WHORE has turned her attention to SAM. SAM looks uncomfortable
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Never tried it? Never? (groping him) I think you are ready, Sam! FENNYMAN shouts a toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are welcome to my best house! Here's to the Admiral's Men! Everybody drinks. VIOLA drinks too. She decides too. She decides to enjoy it. She bangs down her glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Admiral's Men! WILL toasts with her. He sees that she feels one of THE COMPANY. EXT. STREET. NIGHT. A figure is running desperately through the streets. He comes into the square and runs towards the Rose. EXT. BROTHEL. NIGHT. Half THE COMPANY are singing. NOL and a WHORE are tumbling down the stairs together. He is without his trousers. An awful lot of drink has gone down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I...quite liked it. VIOLA, bright eyed, is banging her glass on the table in time to a song which is being drunkenly delivered by a barbershop quartet of actors. FENNYMAN reels into VIOLA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Master Kent! You have not dipped your wick?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My wick?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Fennyman, because you love the theatre you must have a part in my play. I am writing an Apothecary, a small but vital role.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By heaven, I thank you! I will be your Apothecary! In his general enthusiasm, he embraces the next man, who is RALPH, stone cold sober.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am to be in your play.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what is this play about?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, there's this Nurse FENNYMAN, beside himself, shouts for silence, announcing
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Shakespeare has given me the part of the Apothecary!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Apothecary? Will, what is the story? Where is the shipwreck? How does the comedy end?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By God, I wish I knew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By God, Will, if you do not, who does? Let us have pirates, clowns, and a happy ending, or we will send you back to Stratford to your wife! That goes down every well with the entire COMPANY...except for VIOLA and WILL. He looks at her, helplessly, then makes as if to say something. VIOLA ducks away from him and blunders blindly out of the street door, in tears. VIOLA passes PETER who is coming in from the street. WILL, attempting to follow VIOLA, is grabbed round the shoulders by PETER...who, we now see, is in a highly emotional state. WILL tries to fight him off but PETER has the strength of the news he brings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will! Mr. Henslowe! Gentlemen all! He brings the room to silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A black day for us all! There is news come up river from Deptford. Marlowe is dead. There are general gasps and cries for information.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stabbed! Stabbed to death in a tavern at Deptford! No one is more affected than WILL. This second blow is worse than the first. He stands horror-stricken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh...what have I done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was the first man among us. A great light has gone out. EXT. BROTHEL. NIGHT. WILL comes staggering out into the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was I who killed him! God forgive me, God forgive me! He falls into a stagnant puddle, a deep gutter of water and garbage. He gets up and staggers on. EXT. CHURCH TOWER. NIGHT. A church tower looms up in the night sky. INT. CHURCH. NIGHT. This is where WILL has come. The church is empty, but for the demented, grieving figure of SHAKESPEARE, kneeling, praying, weeping, banging his head, in his private purgatory, dimly lit by tallow candles, gazed upon by effigies of the dead and images of his Redeemer. He is wet, bedraggled, weeds and leaves in his hair. EXT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. DAY. A lovely sunny morning. The church bells are ringing. VIOLA and the NURSE, mounted, approach. VIOLA rides sidesaddle on a beautiful horse, and is followed, rather like Quixote by Sancho, by the NURSE on a less impressive animal. Riding in the opposite direction, is WESSEX. And what a happy day it is. He sings and hums to himself merrily. Here is a man who has heard wonderful news. He sees VIOLA and greets her merrily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look sad, my lady! Let me take you riding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is not my riding day, my lord.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bless me, I thought it was a horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am going to church.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand of course. It is to be expected.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is to be expected on a Sunday.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And on a day of mourning. I never met the fellow but once at your house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mourning? Who is dead, my lord?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh!--dear God, I did not think it would be me to tell you. A great loss to playwriting, and to dancing. VIOLA almost faints. The NURSE steadies her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is dead?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Killed last night, in a tavern! Come, then, we'll say a prayer for his soul VIOLA gives a silent cry. The NURSE is speaking to her in distress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lady...my lady...now is the time to show your breeding. INT. CHURCH. DAY. The NURSE is holding VIOLA up as they enter the church. VIOLA seems catatonic. The NURSE lowers her onto a seat and sits down next to her. As they sit, the CHOIR enters singing. WESSEX, who is sitting in the next pew, looks about him with interest. He hasn't been in a church for years. What he sees turns him to jelly. He sees WILL SHAKESPEARE. ANGLE on WILL. WILL is a spectral, bedraggled figure, backlit by a great shaft of light, he would look like a ghost at the best of times, and this is the worst. Bleeding from where he has banged his head, bedraggled and ravaged by the night, he stands in a side chapel staring at WESSEX. WESSEX gasps and sweats, and sees WILL raise a quivering accusatory finger at him. WESSEX cracks. He starts to mumble.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, spare me, dear ghost, spare me for the love of Christ! Now VIOLA sees WILL. She is still paralysed, and seems at first unable to take him in. She watches with detachment as WESSEX starts to back out of the church, finally running in terror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spare me! The CHOIR continues to sing, but the scream brings VIOLA to her senses and she runs to a side door where WILL is leaving. EXT. CHURCH. DAY. Outside, VIOLA sees WILL, staggering away from the church. She calls his name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will! He does not answer. She runs after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, my love, I thought you were dead! She claps him to her. They told each other for a moment then WILL pulls back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is worse. I have killed a man. EXT. MEADOW. DAY. VIOLA'S horse grazes. WILL lies on his back, still sobered and full of guilt. VIOLA sits on the grass among the buttercups and looks down at him. VIOLA is plaiting a finger-ring from stems of grass. She has not yet revealed her feelings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marlowe's touch was in my Titus Andronicus and my Henry VI was a house built on his foundations.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You never spoke so well of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was not dead before. I would exchange all my plays to come for all of his that will never come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You lie. WILL turns to look at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You lie in your meadow as you lied in my bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My love is no lie. I have a wife, yes, and I cannot marry the daughter of Sir Robert de Lesseps. It needed no wife come from Stratford to tell you that. And yet you let me come to your bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Calf love. I loved the writer, and gave up the prize for a sonnet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was the more deceived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes--you were deceived. For I never loved you till now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I love you, Will, beyond poetry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, my love (he kisses her) You ran from me before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were not dead before. When I thought you dead, I did not care about all the plays that will never come, only that I would never see your face. I saw our end, and it will come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cannot marry Wessex!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If not Wessex the Queen will know the cause and there will be no more Will Shakespeare. They kiss again, passionately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No...no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I will go to Wessex as a widow from these vows, as solemn as they are unsanctified. And as their desperate kisses turn into lovemaking we cut to: INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE/AUDITORIUM. DAY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For killing Juliet's kinsman Tybalt, the one who killed Romeo's friend Mercutio, Romeo is banished He is on the stage of the Rose. The entire COMPANY is assembled, HENSLOWE and FENNYMAN included, holding pages of manuscript, which they are sharing together, examining the separated pages, passing pages to each other, etc. WILL'S mood is intense and focused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: but the Friar who married Romeo and Juliet
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that me. Will?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You, Edward. The Friar who married them gives Juliet a potion to drink. It is a secret potion. It makes her seeming dead. She is placed in the tomb of the Capulets. She will awake to life and love when Romeo comes to her side again. THE COMPANY murmurs approval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have not said all. By malign fate, the message goes astray which would tell Romeo of the Friar's plan. He hears only that Juliet is dead. And thus he goes to the Apothecary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And buys a deadly poison. He enters the tomb to say farewell to Juliet who lies there cold as death. He drinks the poison. He dies by her side. And then she wakes and sees him dead. HENSLOWE is fascinated and appalled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And so Juliet takes his dagger and kills herself. PAUSE. WILL is staring at VIOLA HENSLOWE Well, that will have them rolling in the aisles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sad and wonderful! I have a blue velvet cap which will do well, I have seen apothecary with a cap just so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes--it will serve. But there's a scene missing between marriage and death. WILL is still staring at VIOLA. Aware, suddenly, of the others watching, she breaks his gaze and drops her head. WILL looks at NED. INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. EVENING. WILL and VIOLA. VIOLA dressed as THOMAS. He has present for her--a neatly written manuscript of his play, on sheets folded to octavo size.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The play. All written out for you. I had the clerk at Bridewell do it, he has a good fist for lettering. She wants to accept the present with joy, but something in his mood restrains her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a new scene He turns the pages and shows her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you read it for me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Wilt thou be gone? It is not yet near day> It was the nightingale and not the lark That pierced the fearful hollow of thine ear. Nightly she sings on yon pomegranate tree. Believe me, love, it was the nightingale."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "It was the lark, the herald of the morn, No nightingale. Look, love, what envious streaks Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east. Night's candles are burnt out, and jocund day Stands tiptoe on the misty mountain tops. I must be gone and live, or stay and die." The words of the scene become WILL'S and VIOLA'S, their way of saying the farewells they cannot utter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Yon light is not daylight, I know it, I. It is some meteor that the sun exhales To be to thee this night a torchbearer..." INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. BACKSTAGE. DAY. But the scene is continuing with VIOLA dressed as "THOMAS." Somewhere behind and up above the stage, in a deserted corner among rigging, bits of scenery, etc., they speak the lines and we hardly know ourselves whether it is rehearsal or lovemaking. But after a few moments it is definitely lovemaking. Their clothes start coming away, their words interrupted by kisses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...thou need'st not to be gone."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: have more care to stay than will to go. Come death, and welcome. Juliet wills it so. How is't my soul? Let's talk. It is not day." By now, her loosened bosom-bandage has been pulled away and WILL passionately embraces her nakedness. And into this heaving composition comes a little white mouse, unseen my them, climbing through a knot hole in the planking behind VIOLA'S head. An adjacent knot hole reveals a human eye and we do not need to be told it is JOHN WEBSTER'S. WEBSTER takes his eye away from the peephole, and frowns, thinking it out. EXT. ALLEWAY. DAY. TILNEY puts a coin in WEBSTER'S hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will go far, I fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope we work together again. Tilney walks away. EXT. THE ROSE THEATRE. DAY. A man is pacing up and down, in a sort of agony. He is muttering. He is glancing at a sheet of paper. He is FENNYMAN rehearsing the important role of the Apothecary, for which he has a special voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Such mortal drugs I have but Mantua's law Is death to any he that utters them." Then him. Then me. "Put this in any liquid thing you will And..."--something He has dried up. He curses--the terror and despair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Such mortal drugs I have..." What is it? What is it? He is so wrapped up in all this that he simply does not notice when WESSEX rides up to the main entrance dismounts and walks inside. INT. THE ROSE THEATRE. STAGE/AUDITORIUM. DAY. Onstage, the rehearsal continues. WESSEX strides in. Among the audience are HENSLOWE, a few actors...and JOHN WEBSTER...who sees WESSEX and jumps up and goes to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord! WESSEX knocks him aside and continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shakespeare! Everything stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You upstart inky pup! Now I will show you your place, which is in hell!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are on my ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By God, I'll fight the lot of you WILL draws his sword.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am more than enough. VIOLA reacts. She almost gives herself away. But the fight has started. WESSEX slashes at WILL. WILL knows how to fight. He parries and thrusts. WESSEX is surprised. The fight goes fast and furious around the stage, until WILL thrusts accurately at WESSEX'S chest...and would have killed him but for the button on his sword-point. WESSEX grapples with him, and now it becomes a parody of the Hamlet duel; WESSEX'S unbuttoned sword falls to the ground, WILL puts his foot on it, tosses WESSEX his own safe sword, picks up Wessex's sword and continues the fight until he has WESSEX at his mercy. WILL has fought with a passionate rage that has everybody staring at him. Now the look in his eyes is merciless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absent friends! (to the assembly) This is the murderer of Kit Marlowe! NED ALLEYN comes forward looking worried and dubious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I rejoiced at his death because I thought it was yours. That is all I know of Marlowe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's true, Will--it was a tavern brawl...Marlowe attacked, and got his own knife in the eye. A quarrel about the bill
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bill! Oh, vanity, vanity!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not the billing, the bill! WILL steps back, and sinks to his knees. His relief could not be greater.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh God, I am free of it! WESSEX gets to his feet. TILNEY enters the auditorium from the public entrance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My Lord Wessex!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close it! Take it down stone by stone! I want it ploughed into the ground, and sown with quick lime! WESSEX storms out past the bewildered TILNEY.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Tilney, what is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sedition and indecency!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Master of the Revels, sir, over here, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where, boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw her bubbies!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A woman on the stage? A woman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I swear it! THE COMPANY of actors are dumbstruck. None more than VIOLA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, Henslowe! I say this theatre is closed! On the authority of the powers invested in my by the court--I close this theatre!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For lewdness and unshamefacedness! For displaying a female on the public stage! TILNEY is unstoppable. He jumps on the stage...and seizes SAM GOSSE. Before WEBSTER or anyone can intervene, TILNEY pulls up his skirt, ignoring SAM'S rather gutteral yell of protest and pulls down SAM'S drawers. TILNEY'S face is a study. So is everybody else's. WEBSTER rolls his eyes (oh, these stupid grown-ups!) and deftly throws one of his mice onto "ROMEO'S" hair. VIOLA gives a shrill scream, the startled mouse descends her neck via VIOLA'S ear, and seeks an entry into her collar. By which time VIOLA has gone berserk and torn off her wig. Her hair is pinned up but there is no question her gender. WILL is paralysed. VIOLA gives him a look of terrible despair and apology.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not him. (pointing at VIOLA) her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a woman! By now the scene is playing to a crowded theatre, or so it seems.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's who I meant! This theatre is closed! Notice will be posted! SAM has picked himself up, and his drawers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ned, I swear I knew nothing of this!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody knew!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He did! I saw him kissing her bubbies! Everybody looks at WILL, who stares at VIOLA, helpless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Closed! Closed, mark you, Henslowe! TILNEY turns on his heel and leaves in triumph. THE COMPANY is still polaxed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am so sorry, Mr. Henslowe. I wanted to be an actor. (she turns to WILL) I am sorry, Will. WILL shakes his head. This cannot be the end. VIOLA walks away, leaving by the public entrance. They all let her go, watching her silently. As she passes WABASH WABASH Y-y-y-you w-w-w-were w-w-w-w- wonderful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. As she is leaving, WILL comes to life. He starts off towards her...but his progress is halted by a sock to the jaw from NED ALLEYN. WILL falls down in the dust. FENNYMAN enters, still bent over his sheet of paper, mumbling his precious lines. When he reaches the groundlings yard, he finds to his surprise the whole COMPANY is standing about in attitudes of despair or worse. FENNYMAN looks around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything all right? EXT. THE ROSE THEATRE. EVENING. The closure notice is nailed to the door. INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. NIGHT. VIOLA, in her nightdress, is reading by candlelight. She is reading her private manuscript of Romeo and Juliet...and rereading. Next to her is a tray of covered dishes. the NURSE enters and looks at her sympathetically. She lifts the tray. She realises it is heavy. She puts it down and raises the covers and sees that VIOLA has eaten nothing. She looks at VIOLA'S tears, but there is nothing to be said. INT. TAVERN. DAY. They are all there--the ADMIRAL'S MEN, including WILL and HENSLOWE, drowning their sorrows. Everyone is drunk. FENNYMAN is also there, taking the disaster somewhat selfishly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would have been good...I would have been great. He hands a flask to RALPH who is in a similar mood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So would I. We both would. RALPH contemplates the flask, and, since he's not working, takes a swig. A moment later, he keels over, rigid as a pole. The street door crashes open. BURBAGE enters. Behind him enter a solid wedge of the CHAMBERLAIN'S MEN, sober-faced, several with black eyes and bandages round their heads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lambert! LAMBERT, FENNYMAN'S henchman and killer, puts down his tankard and comes forward, casually kicking chairs and tables out of his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kill him! LAMBERT reaches up to the wall over the bar and takes down once of the ceremonial weapons hanging there--a battle-axe. But BURBAGE has flintlock pistol stuck into his sash. BURBAGE draws and the pistol roars, shooting flame, LAMBERT curses, drops the axe, nurses his wounded hand. BURBAGE puts the pistol back into his sash. NED ALLEYN is half-drunk at a table. He staggers to his feet. He faces BURBAGE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Burbage--you never did know when your scene was over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That can wait. The Master of the Revels despises us for vagrants, tinkers, and peddlers of bombast. But my father, James Burbage, had the first licence to make a company of players from Her Majesty, and he drew from poets the literature of the age. Their fame will be our fame. So let them all know, we are men of parts. We are a brotherhood, and we will be a profession. Will Shakespeare has a play. I have a theatre. The Curtain is yours. EXT. THE CURTAIN THEATRE. DAY. A strong wind is blowing through the trees. A BOY with a paste-pot and a bundle of flyers, is having trouble pasting a flyer on the wall of the building. A gust of wind scatters the bundle and sends a couple of dozen flyers flying into the sky. The BOY with the paste-pot runs around, trying to recover those he can. We look at the poster. It says
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BURBAGE A HUGH FENNYMAN PRODUCTION OF MR. HENSLOWE'S PRESENTATION OF THE ADMIRAL'S MEN IN PERFORMANCE OF THE EXCELLENT AND LAMENTABLE TRAGEDY OF ROMEO AND JULIET with Mr. Fennyman as the Apothecary WILL comes out of the theatre, and passes the poster. He walks on without looking at it. A voice calls after him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will! WILL does not turn to look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll be needing a Romeo WILL carries on walking. EXT. STREETS. DAY. WILL is pushing through the crowds on his way to the river. INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. VIOLA'S BEDROOM. DAY. The NURSE is helping VIOLA to dress--in a wedding dress. The NURSE is in tears. VIOLA submits to the task impassively. EXT. THE RIVER. DAY. WILL is climbing down the ladder to the waiting boats. INT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. HALL. DAY. WESSEX, dressed to be a bridegroom is concluding his negotiations with DE LESSEPS, while LADY DE LESSEPS weeps. DE LESSEPS is signing papers. There is a money chest, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My ship is moored at Bankside, bound for Virginia on the afternoon tide--please do not weep, Lady De Lesseps, you are gaining a colony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you are gaining five thousand pounds, my lord...by these drafts in my hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you oblige me with fifty or so in gold?--just to settle my accounts at the dockside? DE LESSEPS sighs and unlocks his money chest. WESSEX places his empty purse on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah!--Look, she comes! VIOLA has appeared at the top of the stairs with the NURSE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, my lord. I see you are open for business so let's to church. EXT. DE LESSEPSES' HOUSE. DAY. WILL is running across the grass towards the house. As he crosses the bridge over the moat, a carriage bears down on him, and he has to flatten himself against the wall of the gatehouse as the carriage passes, taking WESSEX and his bride to church. WILL'S face, as he watches the carriage disappear. Distant bells begin to peal EXT. CHURCH DOOR. DAY. The bells announce the completion of the marriage--as WESSEX and the new LADY WESSEX leave the church. VIOLA'S veil is flying in the wind, and beneath it we can just see VIOLA'S unhappy face. The DE LESSEPS FAMILY entourage is applauding. WESSEX beams with satisfaction. Suddenly the sky and the wind deliver a message--a flyer from the Curtain slaps against WESSEX'S face. He claws at it and tries to throw it away. The wind delivers it to VIOLA'S bosom. She takes it up and reads it. And passes it to the NURSE. WESSEX descends the steps to where the curtained carriage awaits the bride and groom. He gallantly holds the door for VIOLA to enter. She climbs aboard. WESSEX makes to follow her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My lord! The NURSE grasps him in a moving embrace, to WESSEX'S discomfort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be good to her, my lord!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will. He tries to disengage. She won't have it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God bless you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Let go, there's a good nurse. After a couple of further attempts, WESSEX extricates himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tide will not wait. Farewell! WESSEX pulls aside the curtain and gets in. INT. CARRIAGE. DAY. It takes a moment for WESSEX to realise he is alone in there. He looks around but VIOLA has fled. EXT. THE CURTAIN THEATRE. DAY. Hundreds of people are converging on the theatre. Among them is the Puritan MAKEPEACE, vainly exhorting the crowds to run away from sin
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Licentiousness is made a show, vice is made a show, vanity and pride likewise made a show! This is the very business of show But MAKEPEACE is being carried inexorably through the main doors of the theatre. INT. THE CURTAIN THEATRE. BACKSTAGE. DAY. The ADMIRAL'S MEN are all in costume, and are in a buzz of nervous excitement. ALLEYN, dressed for "MERCUTIO," is giving last minute instructions to PETER. JAMES and JOHN HEMMINGS are arguing about the timing of their entrance. FENNYMAN in his apothecary's cap is agonising over his lines. WABASH is stuttering over his. Alone in his dejection in the midst of all this, is WILL, dressed for
direction.name: direction

result.heading: BURBAGE A HUGH FENNYMAN PRODUCTION OF MR
HENSLOWE'S PRESENTATION OF THE ADMIRAL'S MEN IN PERFORMANCE OF THE EXCELLENT AND LAMENTABLE TRAGEDY OF ROMEO AND JULIET
